Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Three Essays on Judicial Decision-Making

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines the impact of electing criminal trial judges on their ability to protect minority rights in the sentencing process. The study utilizes administrative data from Kansas that includes the universe of convicted felons from 1998 to 2010. Kansas is one of only three states that uses both elections (in 14 districts) and appointment (in 17 districts) to choose judges. This variation will allow the PIs to distinguish between judicial appointment modes, controlling for state-specific factors. This research also investigates the extent to which judicial prejudice can be learned or unlearned over time. With more professional experience, it seems plausible that judges could update their prior beliefs as they learn about true race-specific recidivism rates through repeated interactions with both black and white defenders.

A "learning-by-doing" model speaks to the concurrent policy debate over the merits of sentencing guidelines. Since the 1980's, the federal government and numerous states have enacted sentencing guidelines in order to provide more structure in the sentencing process, which in theory, limits racial sentencing disparities by constraining judicial discretion. In practice, there has been mixed evidence on their effectiveness, which raises concerns that preventing judges from utilizing their expertise is unwarranted. If judges do engage in more race-based sentencing earlier rather than later in their careers, then this would suggest tying the guidelines to tenure might be a more effective implementation of this policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Dissertation Grant has been instrumental in advancing our research, which explores different ways in which racial animus influences judicial behavior. Our research project asks whether or not trial judges engage in taste-based racial discrimination. By taste-based discrimination we mean discriminatory behavior that is motivated by socio-psychological racial animus towards one or more racial groups. This question is immensely difficult to answer. The fundamental problem is that judges always have available to them a credible explanation as to why some racial groups are treated differently than others. Racially disparate sentences need not be caused by racial animus, but can be easily rationalized by racial differences in prior records, types of crime, criminal severity, and other relevant case characteristics instead. In other words, blacks may be treated differently not because of their race per se, but because race is statistically correlated with other risk factors that predict future criminality. The fact that researchers never observe all of the myriad factors that judges consider, only makes it more difficult to distinguish between taste-based and statistical discrimination. The existing empirical literature has produced little to no conclusive evidence precisely because there is always valid skepticism as to whether all of the relevant covariates are included in the regression.

We advance the literature by providing a more convincing empirical test of judicial discrimination. We derive the test from a fairly simple theoretical model that combines basic principles of the legal and attitudinal models of judicial behavior. This model-based approach is valuable because it generates clear predictions of how racial animus will affect judicial behavior even when judges engage in statistical discrimination. The test suggests that judicial inconsistency is the key indicator of racial animus. In other words, if a judge is simultaneously the harshest towards one racial group, and the most lenient towards another racial group then this is symptomatic of racial discrimination. Formally, when the rank-order of judge-specific incarceration rates depends on race, then this implies that at least one judge engages in taste-based discrimination against some racial group. This is a fairly intuitive, yet important departure from existing empirical tests that are difficult to interpret precisely because they do not fully account for statistical discrimination. Applying the rank-order test, we find evidence that trial judges in Kansas do indeed exhibit tastes for racial discrimination.
